We're going to steer away from Washington to the car lot.
Faced with an increase in loans gone bad and car repossessions in a down economy, car dealerships are turning to technology to prevent delinquent owners from turning on their cars.
Goodbye repo man, hello disabler.
The disabler is a palm-sized box that is inserted inside the car and wired to the ignition.
Depending on the model the dealer uses, it can send warnings to the driver, or it can shut down the engine entirely.
For more on how these work, we turn to Mark Barr.
He's the general manager at South Jersey Auto Finance.
He joins us from Glassboro, New Jersey.
Hello.
Hello.
So, could you explain how the disabler works?
When do drivers get warnings and when do the dealers cut off the cord?
It depends on what device you use.
The older devices we used to use, the day before the customer's payment's due, it used to beep to let them - remind them.
The new devices we use are more of a cellular base, where we can send a signal at any time to disable the starter.
So we do not send a signal to the customer, any warning to the customer.
However, all our customers know the devices are in the vehicle and why they're used.
So after three days of nonpayment and no contact from the customer, we send the signal to the vehicle to disable the vehicle so the customer will call us
So you don't issue warnings anymore.
Now you just turn it off if they miss a payment.
If they miss a payment and they don't return any of our phone calls.

The keypad device worked very well, however, we had a lot of user error because the customers had to put codes into the device every pay cycle.
